title: Everyday functional ability in the elderly: assessment and inference using brief cognitive tasks
abstractText: There is an increase in the number of healthy elderly individuals in today's society, and the ability to perform everyday tasks independently and safely is a key determinant of quality of life. A key factor affecting the ability to perform complex everyday life tasks is cognitive executive function. This is because functional tasks involve a complex sequence of motor and cognitive sub-tasks which must be organised, supervised and fluently completed in a specific sequence in order to efficiently achieve the targeted end-state. This study investigates both functional ability and cognitive executive function in healthy elderly people in order to understand how they are related.
